H0.text: Checking for errors in the experimental procedure is not something the scientist will most likely do when the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H1.text: Repeat the experiment is the action a scientist will most likely not take if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H2.text: Changing data to support the hypothesis is the action a scientist will most likely not take if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H3.text: Asking new questions is what the scientist will most likely not do if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

A4.text: Failure of an experiment to produce interesting results may lead a scientist to reconsider the experimental method, the hypothesis, or the definition of the subject.

A5.text: At any stage, it is possible to refine its accuracy and precision, so that some consideration will lead the scientist to repeat an earlier part of the process.

A6.text: Those making critical decisions based on the results of a hypothesis test are prudent to look at the details rather than the conclusion alone.

A7.text: In the physical sciences most results are fully accepted only when independently confirmed.

A8.text: This may motivate desperate (or fame-hungry) scientists to fabricate results.

A9.text: Investigators should ensure that uncontrolled influences (e.g., source credibility perception) do not skew the findings of the study.

A10.text: Measurements are usually subject to variation and measurement uncertainty; thus they are repeated and full experiments are replicated to help identify the sources of variation, to better estimate the true effects of treatments, to further strengthen the experiment's reliability and validity, and to add to the existing knowledge of the topic.

A11.text: Even after seeing objective evidence that refuted their working hypotheses, they frequently continued doing the same tests.

A12.text: Data that conflict with the experimenter's expectations may be more readily discarded as unreliable, producing the so-called file drawer effect.

A13.text: One Nature paper published in 2009 has subsequently been reported to contain around 20 separate instances of image fraud.

A14.text: Measurements generally have a small amount of error, and repeated measurements of the same item will generally result in slight differences in readings.

A15.text: Labs with higher scores are more likely to reproduce.

A16.text: In water resources and management, most of 1,987 articles published in 2017 were not replicable because of a lack of available information shared online.
